This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax (maximum velocity of the reaction) is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition.

questions.text: A child presented with recurrent abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea following ingestion of milk-based products. Which enzyme is likely to be deficient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lactase
The given scenario indicates intolerance of milk-based products
in this child, hence, the enzyme likely to be deficient is lactase.
Lactase is the enzyme that is responsible for breaking down
lactose, a disaccharide found in milk and dairy products. When
this enzyme is deficient, it can lead to the accumulation of
lactose in the intestinal lumen where it is fermented by intestinal
bacteria to lactate which produces symptoms of lactose
intolerance, including recurrent abdominal pain, vomiting, and
diarrhea after consuming lactose-rich food items. Lactase and
maltase are present in the intestinal brush border.

questions.text: A child presented to the OPD with complaints of fatigue and muscle weakness while exercising. Laboratory investigations found that LCFA oxidation was affected. A muscle biopsy was done which revealed the presence of fat vacuoles. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Carnitine deficiency
The clinical scenario of a child with fatigue and muscle weakness on exercise with laboratory findings of LCFA oxidation deficiency and fat vacuoles on muscle biopsy suggests a diagnosis of carnitine deficiency.

questions.text: Which micronutrient is most likely deficient in a patient with the radiographic findings given below along with anemia, neutropenia, depigmented hair and skin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Copper

The given clinical features of anaemia and neutropenia, along with depigmented hair and skin and the radiological findings suggestive of pelkan spurs, trummerfeld zone, Frenkel’s line, and Wimberger’s ring sign point to the diagnosis of Menke’s disease. Patients with this condition have low serum levels of copper.

questions.text: A homeless man comes with diarrhea, dementia, and dermatitis. He consumes alcohol occasionally. He admits to having ‘X’ as his staple diet. Which of the following is X most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Maize

This patient with symptoms of dementia, diarrhea and dermatitis most likely has niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency. X is likely to be maize in his diet.
Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, found mostly among people eating corn/maize-based diets, which is low in niacin and tryptophan. Excess leucine in jowar and maize disrupts the conversion of tryptophan to niacin.
Niacin can be synthesized in the body from tryptophan, Two compounds- nicotinic acid, and nicotinamide have the biological activity of niacin. The nicotinamide ring of the coenzymes NAD (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) and NADP (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate) participate in oxidation/reduction reactions.

questions.text: Which protein accumulation is seen in Alzheimer’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aẞ amyloid
Aẞ amyloid deposition is seen in Alzheimer’s disease.
Aẞ constitutes the core of cerebral plaques found in Alzheimer’s disease. It also gets deposited in the walls of cerebral blood vessels. The Aß protein is derived by proteolysis from a much larger transmembrane glycoprotein, called amyloid precursor protein (APP).

questions.text: A mother came back home to see her child suffering from difficulty breathing. The child had contact with rotenone while trying to bathe their pet. The child was taken to the emergency department and she later passed away. Inhibition of which of the following enzymes was the likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

NADH-Q oxidoreductase
In the given clinical vignette, inhibition of NADH-Q oxidoreductase by rotenone was the likely cause of breathlessness, followed by death in this child.

 Rotenone inhibits complex I, thereby inhibiting the respiratory chain, so electrons cannot be transferred to oxygen. This halts ATP production, leading to an energy deficit in the cells, eventually causing cell death. The ETC constitutes four enzyme complexes:
Complex I: NADH-Q oxidoreductase
Complex II: Succinate-Q reductase
Complex III: Q-cytochrome c oxidoreductase
Complex IV: cytochrome c oxidase
Components of complex I are FMN and Fe-S complex.
NADH-Q oxidoreductase catalyses the transfer of electrons from NADH to coenzyme Q, along with the transfer of four H+ across the membrane.

questions.text: A large number of people who consumed cheap alcohol presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain, confusion, and decreased vision. Methyl alcohol level in blood was detected to be around 20 mg %. On assessment which of the following metabolites will be found in blood?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Formic acid and lactic acid
The given case scenario is suggestive of methanol poisoning. In these cases, formic acid and lactic acid are typically the metabolites found in the blood.
Methyl alcohol, or methanol, is commonly present in cheap or illicit alcoholic beverages due to its lower cost compared to ethyl alcohol. These inexpensive alcohols may be improperly distilled or adulterated, leading to methanol contamination. When ingested, methanol is absorbed into the bloodstream and metabolized by the liver, where it is first converted into formaldehyde, a highly toxic intermediate. Formaldehyde is then further oxidized into formic acid, which is responsible for many of the severe symptoms associated with methanol poisoning.

questions.text: A patient with a gynecological malignancy is started on Methotrexate. Later she develops oral and gastric ulcers. Which nucleotide synthesis is affected in her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

TMP

TMP synthesis is affected due to methotrexate.

Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), which is required to synthesize tetrahydrofolate. Tetrahydrofolate is essential for converting dUMP to dTMP (thymidine monophosphate) in the nucleotide synthesis pathway. Therefore, the nucleotide synthesis affected in this patient is TMP (thymidine monophosphate).

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of dermatitis, dementia, and cognitive decline. Which micronutrient deficiency is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Niacin 

The combination of dermatitis, dementia, and cognitive decline is characteristic of pellagra, a condition caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Pellagra is typically associated with the "three D's": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. If left untreated, it can lead to death. Niacin can be derived from the diet, and the body also converts tryptophan (an amino acid) into niacin. However, a deficiency in niacin, rather than tryptophan, is directly responsible for these symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presents with stridor after prolonged intubation. The endoscopic view is shown in the image below. What is the staging system for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cotton Myer
The patient with stridor after prolonged intubation likely has subglottic stenosis, graded by Cotton Myer staging. This condition narrows the airway below the vocal cords, often due to intubation pressure, leading to breathing difficulties. Symptoms include stridor, dyspnea, hoarseness, and voice changes. Diagnosis is made via laryngoscopy or bronchoscopy, while CT or MRI can assess the extent of narrowing. Treatment options include endoscopic  dilation, laser therapy, surgical resection, or tracheostomy in severe cases.

choices.text: Most common site of impaction is at level of cricopharyngeus
One of the constrictions of the esopahgus is at the level of the right bronchus

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding an esophageal foreign body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Most common site of impaction is at level of cricopharyngeus
The most common site for esophageal foreign body impaction is at the cricopharyngeus. Children often ingest coins, disk batteries, and small toys, while adults typically have food bolus impaction, usually meat. In an AP view, a coin shows a flat surface, while its edge appears in a lateral view, indicating it is lodged in the esophagus rather than the trachea.

questions.text: The patient complains of repeated episodes of crusting in the nose with occasional bleeding. She had undergone surgery for nasal obstruction four months back. On examination, the following finding is seen. Which surgery has the highest likelihood to result in this complication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Submucosal resection
The patient’s symptoms of crusting and occasional bleeding after nasal surgery suggest septal perforation, likely resulting from submucosal resection (SMR) for deviated nasal septum (DNS). Smaller perforations may cause whistling, while larger ones lead to epistaxis and crusting. Septoplasty is preferred over SMR for DNS correction due to its conservative approach, retaining more bone and cartilage, and allowing for daycare procedures with fewer complications. Techniques include scoring, shaving, and wedge excision, and in some cases, extra-corporeal septoplasty may be performed for realignment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with mild, progressive, bilateral hearing loss. A PTA showed the following findings. What is the most likely clinical finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Schwartz sign
The scenario describes a 40-year-old woman with mild, progressive bilateral hearing loss and a PTA showing Carhart’s notch, suggesting otosclerosis. The Schwartz sign, a reddish hue on the promontory observed through the tympanic membrane, indicates active disease. Otosclerosis results from bony overgrowth in the otic capsule, causing bilateral conductive hearing loss and tinnitus, with autosomal dominant inheritance. It can worsen with stress and hormonal changes. Stapedial otosclerosis, the most common form, begins near the oval window in the fistula ante fenestrae area.

questions.text: In which procedure is the incision showed in the image used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Open rhinoplasty

The incision shown is used in open rhinoplasty.
This procedure involves a transcolumellar incision, an incision made across the columella to lift the nasal skin, allowing full access to the underlying nasal structures. This approach is used for cosmetic or reconstructive surgery. The open technique allows better visibility of the nasal framework compared to closed rhinoplasty.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with unilateral hearing loss. On examination, a small perforation is noted on his left tympanic membrane. What will be the left-sided Rinne’s test finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Negative
This patient with unilateral hearing loss and a small perforation of his tympanic membrane is likely to have  hearing loss in the left ear, which will show a negative Rinne’s test in the affected ear.
Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning Fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time.

questions.text: A patient presented with recurrent swelling in his lower lip for the past 6 months as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis and treatment option for the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mucous retention cyst: Excision

The given scenario of recurrent swelling on the lip for 6 months and the image showing soft, and transparent cystic swelling points to a diagnosis of a mucous retention cyst. It has to be managed by an excision.
Mucous retention cysts result from duct obstruction by periductal scars or sialolithiasis (salivary gland stone formation) These cysts are mainly found in the ductal system of a minor salivary gland. The cyst cavity may contain fragments of a sialolith or mucous material. Some may regress spontaneously but best management is done by an excision.

choices.text: Ideal position for bougie insertion in emergencies

questions.text: What is true about the following position?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sniffing position for intubation
The above image shows the sniffing position used for intubation,
which is the true statement.
The sniffing position is a common head and neck alignment
technique used during intubation to optimize the view of the
glottis for easier insertion of the endotracheal tube. It is achieved
by flexing the neck and extending the head, resembling the
posture one assumes when sniffing. The position aligns the oral,
pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes to provide a straight line of sight,
making the glottis more visible during direct laryngoscopy and
intubation.

choices.text: Unresponsive patient, pulse and breathing absent
Responsive patient, pulse and breathing present
Unresponsive patient, pulse and breating present

questions.text: This recovery position is appropriate for.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Unresponsive patient, pulse and breating present
The position illustrated in the picture is known as the recovery position, and it is used in the management of patients who are unresponsive but with pulse present and breathing present.
The recovery position can help prevent complications such as aspiration and airway obstruction in unconscious individuals. Additionally, it is crucial to continuously monitor the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation while in recovery and seek immediate medical assistance. An unresponsive patient who is breathing spontaneously in the supine position is at risk of airway obstruction from their tongue, mucus, vomit, etc.

questions.text: For standards of ventilation, the widely quoted standard is that of De Chaumont who advocated a fresh air supply of 3000 cubic feet per person per hour. It is calculated based on which parameter?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) CO2 content of air For standards of ventilation, CO2 content of air is the paramater used to calculate fresh air supply of 3000 cubic feet per person per hour which was advocated by De Chaumont. Ventilation involves the quality control of incoming air but not quality control of outgoing air. It also involves the replacement of vitiated air(air with decreased oxygen content) by a supply of fresh outdoor air. It aims to provide a comfortable thermal environment and reduce the risk of infections. Fresh air supply of 3000 cubic feet per person per hour is a good standard for air requirement. It is observed that the amount of CO2 due to respiration is not more than 2 parts in 1000 parts of air, then the air in the room is considered fresh.

questions.text: At what pressure does the marked structure open?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

30-40 cm H2O

In the image, the marked structure is the adjustable pressurelimiting
(APL) valve of Mapelson-C anaesthetic breathing
system and it will open at the pressure of 30-40 cm H2O. This
valve is designed to release gas when a certain pressure is
exceeded to prevent excessive pressure from building up in the
patient’s airway.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing implant surgery for his upper limb. On giving general anaesthesia he develops tachycardia, sudden raise in body temperature and rigidity of muscles. What drug is most likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Halothane
In the clinical scenario given above, the development of
tachycardia and muscle rigidity soon after administration of
anesthetic agents can be due to malignant hyperthermia.
Halothane is the anesthetic agent associated with this condition.
Malignant hyperthermia is a rare genetic hypermetabolic disease
of the muscle. It occurs due to a mutation of the gene for the
ryanodine receptor (Ryr 1), located on chromosome 19. It is an
ion channel responsible for calcium release from the
sarcoplasmic reticulum.

questions.text: What is the procedure being done in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bier Block

The position in the image of a hand with a tourniquet occluded limb shows a Bier Block.
IVRA or Bier’s block involves the intravenous administration of a local anesthetic into a tourniquet-occluded limb. It is used to provide anesthesia for short surgical procedures (<90 minutes) on the limbs.

questions.text: 3-month-old child was brought to the clinic with a history of difficulty in feeding and failure to thrive. On examination, the child is floppy, 48 cm in length and weighs 2.8 kg. There is generalized hypotonia, macroglossia and hepatomegaly. The chest x-ray of the child is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pompe’s disease
The child's symptoms of feeding difficulties, failure to thrive,
generalized hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, and
massive cardiomegaly on chest X-ray suggest Pompe's disease.
This glycogen storage disorder (type II) is caused by a
deficiency of lysosomal acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase),
leading to glycogen accumulation in the liver (hepatomegaly),
skeletal muscles (hypotonia and weakness), and cardiac muscles
(hypertrophic cardiomyopathy). Children typically die by age 2
from cardiac failure, while the adult form presents with muscle
dystrophies. Laboratory findings include elevated serum creatine
kinase (CK), AST, ALT, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).
Urine glucose tetrasaccharides serve as a biomarker for disease
severity and treatment response. Treatment involves enzyme
replacement therapy with recombinant alpha-glucosidase
(Myozyme).

questions.text: A newborn baby presented with a difficulty in breathing. Auscultation of the chest revealed gurgling sounds and heart sounds shifted to the right. The chest radiograph confirmed a congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Which among the following is the most common location for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Left posterolateral Congenital diaphragmatic hernia with the features given in the clinical vignette occurs most commonly in a left posterolateral defect.

Bochdalek hernia is the most common congenital diaphragmatic hernia which occurs on the left posterolateral side due to a defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane. The abdominal contents in the thorax compress the developing lungs causing pulmonary hypoplasia which manifests as respiratory distress in most infants. Chest X-ray shows an indistinct diaphragm with radiolucent para cardiac shadow and absent bowel loops in the abdomen. Opacities can be seen in the thorax if solid organs or omentum also herniate. Surgical repair is indicated in all cases either by a thoracic or abdominal approach.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the emergency department with lethargy, difficulty feeding, and dehydration. His vitals are stable and his ECG is shown below. What is the next step in his management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Adenosine 0.1 mg/kg
This clinical history along the EKG showing narrow QRS
complexes without P waves and pseudo R waves in aVR lead
suggests paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) and
the next step in his management would be an initial dose of
adenosine at 0.1 mg/kg.

questions.text: The method shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Burns Marshall Technique
The image shows Marshall Burns’s technique used in the delivery of aftercoming head in breech delivery.
Technique:
- Baby is allowed to hang by its weight till the nape of the neck is visible
- When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, the baby is grasped by the ankles
- Baby is swung in an arc in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen

questions.text: A woman presents with lower abdominal pain. Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) performed over two days reveals a left adnexal cystic mass with a cogwheel appearance, incomplete septa, and no vascular flow on Doppler imaging. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hydrosalphinx

Transvaginal ultrasound shows a left adnexal cystic mass with incomplete septa and no vascular flow, indicating hydrosalpinx. This condition is a chronic cystic swelling of the fallopian tube due to distal tubal obstruction. The cogwheel appearance and distended tubes filled with clear serous fluid support the diagnosis. Histologically, the tubal plicae are flattened, with the interstitial end open and the fimbrial end closed, allowing dye entry but not exit during HSG.

questions.text: What is the time taken for the embryo to travel from point 1 to 8?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

8 days
The embryo takes approximately 8 days to travel from point 1 (fertilization) to point 8 (implantation) (typically 6-7 days).
Timeline of implantation:
- 3-4 days after fertilization: The morula (12-16 cells) enters the uterus.
- 4th day after fertilization: The advanced morula reaches the uterine lumen.
- 4-5 days after fertilization: The early blastocyst stage is seen.
- 6-7 days after fertilization: The blastocyst implants in the uterus. Implantation corresponds to 20-22 days of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with menorrhagia. A hysterectomy was performed, and the specimen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intramural Fibroid

The given clinical scenario as well as the specimen suggests that this is a case of leiomyoma uteri or fibroid uterus. The specimen is of a leiomyoma.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman, P2L2, who had her last pregnancy 20 years ago, presents with heavy bleeding. A smooth, round, globular structure is observed on examination. On bimanual examination, the uterus is described as multiparous and firm, and the cervix admits one finger. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Myomatous Polyp

The clinical scenario describes a smooth, globular structure and heavy menstrual bleeding, suggesting a myomatous polyp, or fibroid polyp. This benign tumor originates from uterine smooth muscle cells (leiomyomas) and can protrude from the endometrial cavity or cervix, often appearing as a smooth, pinkish mass. Symptoms include heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, and pressure. These polyps may be attached to the uterine wall by a stalk, contributing to their globular appearance.

questions.text: An unmarried girl presents with amenorrhea and abdominal pain. On genital examination, she is found to have a softened cervix. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Goodell’s Sign

The sign present in this girl is called Goodell’s sign. Goodell’s sign is a sign of early pregnancy, which describes the marked softening of the cervix in contrast to the non-pregnant state. It is seen as early as the 6th week.

questions.text: A woman undergoing infertility treatment is found to have bilateral tubal blockage on hysterosalpingography. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Laparoscopic chromopertubation

The next step for a patient with bilateral tubal blockage on hysterosalpingography is laparoscopic chromopertubation. Tubal contractions can lead to false-positive results for proximal fallopian tube obstruction. Laparoscopy with chromotubation confirms the diagnosis and allows for therapeutic interventions. This procedure involves visualizing pelvic structures and injecting methylene blue dye through the cervix to assess tubal patency, while also diagnosing peritubal adhesions, endometriosis, and other pelvic abnormalities.

questions.text: A primigravida experienced precipitous labor while being transported In an ambulance. Upon arrival at the hospital, the given injury is observed. What type of injury is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

4th degree perineal tear
The image shows a grade 4 perineal tear, extending to the rectal mucosa. This differentiates it from a grade 3 tear, which involves the vaginal mucosa, perineal skin, perineal muscles, and anal sphincter but not the rectal mucosa. Minor perineal injuries are common, especially in first births, while severe third or fourth-degree tears often result from mismanagement during the second stage of labor. Proper management of this stage can help prevent these injuries.

questions.text: Identify the forceps typically used for delivering the aftercoming head in a breech delivery.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Piper’s forceps

The image shows Piper’s forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve. It is used to assist in the delivery of the after-coming head of breech.
It has a cephalic curve, reverse pelvic curve, and long parallel shanks that permit the baby’s body to rest against it during head delivery. It may be applied electively or when the Mauriceau maneuver cannot be accomplished easily.

choices.text: Keep the IUCD in place and continue prophylactic antibiotics
Keep the IUCD in place without any treatment
Remove the IUCD immediately and continue pregnancy
Terminate the pregnancy because of high risk of infection

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady, G3P2 with 10 weeks intrauterine gestation comes to OPD with an Intra Uterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD) and the tail of the IUCD is noted to be protruding from the cervical os. The most appropriate course of action is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Remove the IUCD immediately and continue pregnancy

The best course of action for this patient at 10 weeks of gestation is to remove the IUCD immediately and continue the pregnancy. If the IUD strings are visible and the pregnancy is under 13 weeks, prompt removal is recommended to prevent complications such as septic abortion and premature birth. In cases where the strings are not visible, an ultrasound should be performed to locate the IUD. If the IUD is confirmed to be present, the management options include therapeutic abortion, ultrasound-guided removal of the IUD, or continuing the pregnancy with the IUD left in place.

questions.text: A woman presents with chronic lower abdominal pain that worsens during menstruation. Ultrasound reveals a right adnexal mass with homogeneous echoes. MRI shows a 4x5 cm T1 hyperintense lesion without fat suppression, while the T2 sequence demonstrates low signal intensity with characteristic dark shading. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Endometrioma

The most likely diagnosis is endometrioma. The patient’s chronic lower abdominal pain, which worsens during menstruation, and the ultrasound finding of a right adnexal mass with homogeneous echoes are highly suggestive of an endometrioma.
Endometriosis is defined by the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue at a site outside of the uterus. It is a benign condition but it is locally invasive. Some common sites of endometriosis are ovaries, pelvic peritoneum, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, rectovaginal septum, and sigmoid colon. Endometriosis in the ovaries is called endometrioma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female, P2L2, presents with a mass per vaginum. On examination, infravaginal elongation of the cervix is noted. How will you treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fothergill surgery

The appropriate treatment for a 30-year-old female with infravaginal elongation of the cervix is Fothergill surgery.
Fothergill surgery, or the Manchester operation, involves performing an anterior colporrhaphy combined with the amputation of the cervix. During the procedure, the Mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in front of the cervix, and the operation concludes with a colpoperineorrhaphy. This surgical approach is particularly suitable for women under 40 years old who wish to maintain reproductive function, although it’s important to note that fertility may be reduced following the procedure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old P2L2 woman presents with complaints of a mass descending through the vagina and wishes to retain her fertility. She underwent an abdominal sling procedure with mesh placement. Which is the correct site of attachment of the mesh?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sacral Promontory
In abdominal sling procedures such as sacral colpoреху, which is used to treat pelvic organ prolapse while preserving fertility, the mesh is typically attached to the sacral promontory. This site provides strong support for the prolapsed vaginal apex and allows for a durable suspension without significant compromise to the patient’s fertility.

questions.text: A woman who had a mediolateral episiotomy during normal labor presents with pain at the episiotomy site, which worsens during her menstrual periods. The findings noted on episiotomy site exploration are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Endometriosis
This patient presenting with symptoms of cyclical pain at the episiotomy site with image showing perineal scar endometriosis has ectopic endometrial tissue.
Endometriosis can occur at the site of a surgical scar and typically presents with cyclical pain that corresponds with the menstrual cycle. The extra-uterine sites of endometrial tissue are influenced by cyclical changes in the hormone levels which give rise to location-specific symptoms as mentioned above.

questions.text: During a lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) for a patient with a breech presentation, following findings were noted as given in the image. On per vaginal examination, two cervices are felt. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Uterine Didelphys
The most likely diagnosis in this patient with two cervices on examination and two uterine domes as seen in the image is uterine didelphys. It is a congenital anomaly where there are two separate uterine cavities and two cervices, each with its own set of endometrial lining.
Uterine didelphys is commonly associated with renal anomalies such as unilateral renal agenesis, severe renal hypoplasia, etc, and is often associated with
- Recurrent pregnancy loss
- Preterm labor
- Malpresentations
- Prematurity
Per speculum examination will reveal two cervices in such women.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the procedure shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Primigravida
The procedure shown in the image is the external cephalic version (ECV). Being a primigravida (first pregnancy) is not a contraindication to ECV. The procedure can be performed in both primigravida and multigravida patients as long as other contraindications are not present.

questions.text: A woman presents with lower abdominal pain. Ultrasound reveals a right adnexal mass with septations. Which tumor markers would be most appropriate to order in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CA125, AFP, HCG, LDH

In cases of adnexal masses, particularly when considering the possibility of ovarian cancer or germ cell tumors, the following tumor markers are useful:

choices.text: Ampulla; as it has more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles
Ampulla; as it is the widest part
Isthmus; as it has uniform muscle thickness
Isthmus; as it is the narrowest part

questions.text: What is the most common site for tubal ligation and the reason for ligation at this site?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Isthmus; as it has uniform muscle thickness
The most common site for tubal ligation is the isthmus of the fallopian tube due to its uniform muscle thickness, which facilitates effective occlusion.
The isthmus, being a narrow segment closest to the uterine wall, provides an ideal location for surgical intervention. This site ensures a more reliable and efficient ligation, minimizing the risk of complications and maximizing the success rate of the procedure. The uniformity of the muscle layer at this location allows for a consistent occlusion technique. Common procedures for tubal ligation at this site include the Pomeroy method, where a loop of the tube is tied and excised, and other techniques like the Falope ring or the electrocoagulation method.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman at 10 weeks of gestation, comes to you for medical termination of pregnancy. Which method would you prefer for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mifepristone and Misoprostol
Misoprostol and mifepristone are administered during first trimester to induce medical termination of pregnancy.
200mg of mifepristone is administered orally on day 1. The minimum recommended interval between mifepristone & misoprostol is 24 hours. 24-48 hours later, misoprostol 800 mcg is administered by the vaginal, sublingual, or buccal route. Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14.

choices.text: Routine measurement of serum magnesium levels
Deep tendon reflexes should be present

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman at 34 weeks of gestation is admitted for preeclampsia with severe features, and you have administered MgSO4, as prophylaxis. Which of the following is not a part of monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Routine measurement of serum magnesium levels
Routine measurement of serum magnesium levels is not typically required unless clinical signs of toxicity (e.g., loss of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory depression, decreased urine output) are present.
MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. It can also be used as a tocolytic to stop preterm labor. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L.

questions.text: A woman’s vaginal sample shows an abnormal Nugent’s score. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bacterial Vaginosis

The most likely diagnosis is bacterial vaginosis.
Nugent’s criteria is used to evaluate three types of bacteria. In a case of suspected bacterial vaginosis: Mobiluncus, Lactobacillus, and Gardnerella/Bacteroides. Bacteria are graded through the gram stain of vaginal samples.

choices.text: Primary oocyte with meiosis I completed
Secondary oocyte arrested in meiosis II
Primary oocyte arrested in meiosis I
Secondary oocyte with meiosis II completed

questions.text: After ovulation, in which phase is the released egg arrested?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Secondary oocyte arrested in meiosis II
After ovulation, the released egg is arrested in meiosis II.
The released egg is in the secondary oocyte stage, having completed meiosis I. It then enters meiosis II, but this process is arrested at metaphase II until fertilization occurs. If fertilization takes place, meiosis II will be completed; otherwise, the secondary oocyte remains arrested in meiosis II.
Oogenesis is the process wherein oogonia differentiate into mature oocytes. It begins before birth. At birth, there are approximately 2 million primordial follicles. Primordial germ cells divide by mitosis to form oogonia.

choices.text: It occurs in hot and dry temperatures
It is a type of body preservation with saponification of fats
Occurs within few hours of death

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who was found dead was brought in for autopsy. The doctor notices a greyish-white waxy layer over the body with preserved facial features. Which of the following statements is true concerning adipocere formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 It is a type of body preservation with saponification of
fats
Adipocere formation is a late postmortem change where body
fats undergo saponification, resulting in a waxy substance
known as corpse wax. This process occurs days to months after
death, producing a greyish-white material with a characteristic
sweet or offensive odor. Typically, significant adipocere changes
take several months, although in temperate climates during
summer, it can start in as little as three weeks. In some cases, it
can take thre

questions.text: A pregnant female comes to a gynaecologist, who sends her for USG. On USG, twin pregnancy was noted with about a one-month difference in the age of fetuses. Which of the following is true with regard to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Superfetation
The phenomenon is called superfetation, occurring when two
different ova are fertilized in separate menstrual cycles, resulting
in two children born simultaneously, one possibly mature and
the other immature, or two fully developed fetuses born one to
three months apart. Ovulation typically halts during pregnancy,
but in some cases, it can continue into the first trimester,
allowing for fertilization of a new ovum while already pregnant.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with findings as shown below. Identify the type of poisoning in this patient.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Arsenic
The image showing the raindrop pattern of skin pigmentation
and the Aldrich-Mees lines on the fingernails of the patient are
suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning.
Arsenic in its metallic form is not poisonous, but when it unites
with oxygen, it forms poisonous vapours of arsenic trioxide.
These interfere with cellular respiration, damaging
mitochondrial enzymes. It is present in fruit sprays, copper and
gold mineral deposits, weed killers, insecticides, rat poisons,
wallpapers, and artificial flowers.

questions.text: The following findings were noted during the autopsy of a patient with a gunshot injury. What is the likely range of the gunshot?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Close range The likely range of the gunshot injury shown above is close range, characterized by a circular wound with blackening and tattooing.

choices.text: Patient could sue the doctor for removing her uterus
Hysterectomy was done as a life-saving procedure, so the doctor is legally protected
Consent can be taken from the patient on the OT table
Counseling of patient and attendants is not needed

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman G3P2L2 in active labor experienced arrested labor at 8 cm dilation. After delivering via emergency cesarean section, she developed severe postpartum hemorrhage. Conservative measures failed, leading to an emergency hysterectomy. What are the medicolegal implications of this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hysterectomy was done as a life-saving procedure, so
the doctor is legally protected.
Under IPC Section 30 (BNS), a doctor can perform life-saving
procedures like an emergency hysterectomy without consent if
conservative measures fail. Delaying treatment for consent could
harm the patient, known as the doctrine of anticipation. In
emergencies, informed consent may be unnecessary.

questions.text: A person comes to emergency after consumption of a substance, the form and dose of which is not known to the relatives. The patient has tachypnea and hypotension. On metabolic assessment, high anion gap metabolic acidosis is noted with hypocalcemia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ethylene glycol

The patient’s presentation of tachypnea, hypotension, high anion gap metabolic acidosis, and hypocalcemia, is suggestive of ethylene glycol poisoning.
Ethylene glycol is a clear, colourless, and odourless liquid commonly used as an antifreeze. It is known for its bitter-sweet taste and is absorbed mainly through ingestion rather than skin contact. Upon ingestion, ethylene glycol is metabolized in the liver to several toxic metabolites, including glycolic acid and oxalic acid, which contribute to its harmful effects.

choices.text: Present only in the bone marrow
Dried outer wall contains silica and chlorophyll
It is a microscopic unicellular bacteria
It is not heat and acid resistant

questions.text: In the case of drowning, following autopsy, an organism was isolated from the water present in the internal organs. Which of the following is true regarding the isolated organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dried outer wall contains silica and chlorophyll

Diatoms enter pulmonary circulation on antemortem drowning. Diatoms are a class of microscopic unicellular algae found suspended in most natural waters. Their cell walls are impregnated with silica, chlorophyll,  and a brown pigment.
The drowning fluid and the particles in it, e.g., diatoms and plankton, pass from the ruptured alveolar wall into lymph channels and pulmonary veins and thus enter the left heart. Only a live body with circulation could transport diatoms from the lungs to the brain, bone marrow, liver and other viscera, and skeletal muscle. They are also found in bile and urine. Bone marrow is highly suitable and reliable.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man died following a RTA. The doctor informed the police officer and shifted the body to the mortuary. Autopsy in this case will be conducted at the request of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Investigating police officer
In the case of the 36-year-old man who died following an RTA, the autopsy will be conducted at the request of the investigating police officer.
According to BNSS Section 194 (Section 174 CrPC), a police inquest is the standard procedure for investigating unnatural deaths in India. This process is typically carried out by a police officer, not below the rank of Senior Head Constable, who is responsible for conducting a preliminary inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the death.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl child came agitated to the emergency department after consuming some drug with a previous history of suicidal tendencies. The parents do not know the mode and route of the drug administered. She presented with tachycardia, tachypnea, diaphoresis, and dilated pupils. What is the likely drug administered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cocaine
In the given clinical scenario, the patient presenting with tachycardia, tachypnea, diaphoresis, and dilated pupils after consuming some drug with a previous history of suicidal tendencies points towards a diagnosis of cocaine toxicity leading to sympathetic toxidrome.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy comes with visual disturbances and a headache. On imaging, he was found to have a suprasellar lesion. On biopsy and examination, the tumour exuded “black motor oil” like fluid. The MRI image is shown below. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Craniopharyngioma
The clinical scenario and MRI findings of an intracranial mass
with calcification at the sella turcica, along with histopathology
showing a black motor oil appearance, suggest
craniopharyngioma. These tumors arise from remnants of
Rathke’s pouch and typically present bimodally. In children,
symptoms include headaches, short stature, bitemporal
hemianopsia (due to optic chiasma compression), and polyuria.
Craniopharyngiomas are large, heterogeneous lesions with solid
and cystic components, containing cholesterol-rich, thick
brownish-yellow fluid, and show radiologically demonstrable
calcification.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with hearing loss in the left ear and episodic pulsatile tinnitus. On examination, there was a mass in the middle ear behind the tympanic membrane. A CT performed is as shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Glomus jugulare
The clinical vignette describes a woman with hearing loss and
pulsatile tinnitus, with examination suggesting a mass behind
the tympanic membrane and a CT showing a mass in the jugular
foramen, indicating a likely diagnosis of Glomus Jugulare.
These are the most common benign tumors of the middle ear,
arising from paraganglionic cells in glomus bodies, which
resemble carotid bodies. They typically affect females aged 40-
50, grow slowly, and may take years for symptoms to appear.
Glomus tumors follow the "rule of 10s": 10% are familial, 10%
are multicentric, and 10% are functional (secreting
catecholamines).

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presented with seizures which subsided with injection Midazolam. Blood investigations and lumbar puncture studies were normal. MRI is done and the image is given below. What is the next best investigation of choice for further assessment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

MR spectroscopy
The clinical history of a child and MRI findings of a ringenhancing
intraaxial brain lesion suggest either a tuberculoma or
neurocysticercosis. MR spectroscopy is the next best
investigation for further assessment. This non-invasive test
analyzes metabolite distribution in brain tissue, measuring Nacetyl
aspartate (NAA) for neuronal viability, choline for
cellular turnover, creatine for metabolic activity, lipids
indicating cell membrane disruption, and lactate as a marker of
anaerobic metabolism.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Chronic calicific pancreatitis
As the given image shows, there are multiple calcifications
within the region of the pancreas, which is characteristic of
chronic calcific pancreatitis.

choices.text: Mediastinal mass with fat and calcification
This is characteristic of mediastinal Hydatid cyst

questions.text: A patient came with a history of dyspnea. His CT scan is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mediastinal mass with fat and calcification

In a patient with dyspnea, a CT scan shows a mediastinal mass with an attenuation of -62 HU, indicative of fat content, along with areas of calcification. This suggests the presence of a mediastinal mass comprised of fat and calcified tissue.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Chiari type 1 
The MRI image in the question shows a downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, which is
characteristic of Chiari type 1 malformation.

questions.text: Identify the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Barium swallow

The given image shows a barium swallow. It is a type of Imaging where the patient ingests barium, a contrast agent, to visualize the esophagus and detect abnormalities. The described indentations in the esophageal lumen caused by anterior osteophytes (bony outgrowths) are characteristic findings that can be seen with a barium swallow.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with complaints of fever for 5 days and there were no signs of meningitis. MRI with diffusion-weighted and contrast are shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Brain abscess

The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever without evidence of meningitis along with an image showing a ring-enhancing lesion with enhancement on diffusion-weighted MRI (Diffusion restriction) is suggestive of Brain abscess.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with a bone tumor showing a sunburst appearance on imaging?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Osteosarcoma
A bone tumor with a sunburst appearance on imaging is most likely osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the commonly involved sites.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency room following a bike accident. Examination reveals the right upper limb in abduction and external rotation. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anterior Dislocation of the Shoulder
The upper limb in abduction and external rotation and radiograph are both suggestive of anterior dislocation of the shoulder. The AP view radiograph shows the disturbed articulation between the humeral head and glenoid fossa. The humeral head is seen below and medial to the glenoid socket. This suggests anterior dislocation of the shoulder joint. In young adults, the common cause for anterior dislocation is athletic injuries, while in older adults, falls are a more common cause.

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. An X-ray taken after fracture management is shown below. By which of the following mechanisms will fracture healing occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Primary healing

The clinical vignette describes a child with a fracture treated with compression plating, leading to primary healing without
callus formation. The stages of fracture healing are: 

Hematoma Stage (up to 7 days): Ischemic necrosis occurs as the periosteum detaches, killing some osteocytes while others aid
healing.
Granulation Tissue Stage (2-3 weeks): Daughter cells differentiate into blood vessels, fibroblasts, and osteoblasts,
forming soft granulation tissue. 

Callus Stage (4-12 weeks): Granulation tissue develops into osteoblasts producing a callus (woven bone), visible on X-rays
around 3 weeks post-fracture.


Remodeling Stage (1-2 years): Woven bone is replaced by mature lamellar bone (secondary callus).

Modeling Stage: Bone strengthens and reshapes in response to weight-bearing stresses.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female patient presents with a pathological fracture of the hip and femur. Her serum calcium and phosphate are increased. DEXA scan confirms decreased bone density. Which of the following parameters will increase in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tartrate resistant acid phosphatase 
In this patient, the pathological fracture and elevated serum calcium and phosphate suggest a possible metabolic bone disease such as Paget’s disease of bone. The parameter likely to be increased is TRAP (tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase), which is a marker of osteoclast activity.

TRAP is an enzyme produced by osteoclasts, which are cells responsible for bone resorption.

Elevated levels of TRAP are often seen in conditions with increased bone turnover, such as Paget’s disease, hyperparathyroidism, and certain bone malignancies.

questions.text: A patient presents with sciatica and tenderness in the hamstring muscles. Which nerve supplies the hybrid muscle that is likely to be spared in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Obturator nerve

The adductor magnus is the hybrid muscle that is likely to be spared in this condition.

In sciatica, the sciatic nerve is typically affected, which branches into the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve. The adductor magnus muscle is an example of a hybrid muscle with dual innervation:

- The adductor part of the adductor magnus is innervated by the obturator nerve.

- The hamstring part of the adductor magnus is innervated by the tibial nerve. During sciatica,

During sciatica, the tibial nerve is often affected, which would impact the hamstring part of the adductor magnus. However, because the adductor part of the adductor magnus is innervated by the obturator nerve, it remains functional and is likely to be spared.

choices.text: Pain and temperature was lost in right leg

questions.text: A patient suffered from RTA. After a few days, he had exaggerated right-sided extensor plantar reflex and knee jerk. What other finding would be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ankle clonus in right foot

The scenario indicates an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion due to trauma, likely causing ankle clonus in the right foot. UMN lesions involve corticospinal and brainstem neurons, leading to spasticity, hypertonia, and hyperreflexia. Normally, painful stimulation of the foot results in plantar flexion of the toes, but with a UMN lesion, there is an extensor plantar response (positive Babinski sign), where the great toe extends and other toes may fan out.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with chronic lower back pain. MRI of the lower back shows the following findings. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Spondylolisthesis

The above clinical scenario, the history and MRI scan are suggestive of spondylolisthesis.

Spondylolisthesis is the anterior displacement of a vertebra over another, usually at the lower lumbar spine. Occasionally, the
displacement is backward (retrolisthesis). It is characterized by chronic back pain, lumbar lordosis, and step sign. Normally,
spinous processes of adjacent vertebrae can be palpated on the back smoothly. In spondylolisthesis, a step-off or step sign can
be felt over the spinous process at the affected level.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child fell down the stairs. An X-ray was done. Identify the structure injured as marked in the X-ray.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tibial tuberosity

The given X-ray points towards the tibial tuberosity. This image shows an avulsion fracture of the tibial tuberosity.

The tibial tuberosity is a bony prominence located on the anterior part of the tibia, just below the knee. It is the attachment
point for the patellar tendon. Injury to the tibial tuberosity is common in adolescents, especially those Involved in sports or
after trauma like a fall.

questions.text: A 21-year-old patient with a history of a fracture had a cast applied. On removal of the cast, the following deformity was seen. What is the most likely cause of this deformity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Supracondylar humerus fracture

The given image shows cubitus varus deformity, where the forearm has deviated medially in relation to the upper arm,
which is a common complication of supracondylar humeral fracture. 

Malunion is the commonest complication of a supracondylar fracture and results in a cubitus varus deformity, also known as
gunstock deformity. This occurs when the fracture unites with the distal fragment tilted medially and in internal rotation.

questions.text: A fracture line passing through which of these will impair longitudinal growth of the bone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Epiphyseal plate

A fracture line passing through the epiphyseal plate (also known as the growth plate) will impair the longitudinal growth of the
bone.
The epiphyseal plate is the area of growing tissue near the ends of the long bones in children and adolescents. It is responsible
for bone lengthening (longitudinal growth). If the fracture involves the epiphyseal plate, it can disrupt this process and lead
to growth disturbances or deformities.

questions.text:
patient complains of decreased sensation in the lateral three-and-a-half fingers on the palmar side of the right hand, along with difficulty moving the upper phalanx of the
thumb. Examination reveals thenar atrophy. Which of the following structures, when affected, lead to this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Carpal tunnel

The most likely nerve injured here is the median nerve, which occurs in Carpal tunnel syndrome.

choices.text: Start her on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors

questions.text: A girl was referred to psychiatry by a plastic surgeon after repeatedly seeking full facial reconstruction. She complains of nonexistent dark spots on her face and insists she is ugly, frequently checking her reflection in mirrors and spoons. Despite her mother's reassurances, she remains fixated on surgery. What should the psychiatrist do?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Start her on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors
The case suggests body dysmorphic disorder (BDD),
characterized by an intense preoccupation with perceived flaws
in appearance that are often minor or nonexistent. The
psychiatrist should prescribe selective serotonin reuptake
inhibitors (SSRIs) to address her symptoms. Individuals with
BDD may engage in behaviors such as mirror-checking,
comparing themselves to others, camouflaging perceived flaws,
and avoiding social situations due to their appearance concerns.
This focus on appearance distinguishes BDD from other
conditions involving repetitive behaviors.

questions.text: 19-year-old presented to the psychiatry OPD. He has a charming persona and is well-composed and behaved in front of interviewers. His mother complains of him getting into fights and bunking classes, drinking alcohol and getting involved in police cases. What kind of personality disorder does he have?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Antisocial The patient most likely has antisocial personality disorder. Although the patient seems charming and well-composed, he is aggressive and clearly exhibits disregard for social norms, and shows no remorse for his actions. These findings are characteristic of antisocial personality disorder. Antisocial Personality Disorder is characterized by a long-term pattern of manipulation, exploitation, or violation of others’ rights. Individuals with antisocial personality disorder tend to show no regard for right or wrong and often disregard the feelings, rights, and safety of others.

questions.text: If a child with ADHD goes untreated into adolescence, what is he most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Conduct disorder
If untreated, a child with ADHD is most likely to develop
conduct disorder in adolescence. ADHD often persists into
adulthood, with hyperactivity potentially diminishing but
attention and impulse-control issues remaining. Individuals with
ADHD are at higher risk for conduct disorder, antisocial
behavior, substance use disorders, and mood disorders. ADHD
is a neuropsychiatric condition marked by reduced attention
span and increased impulsivity, with the prefrontal cortex and
dopamine implicated in its etiology.

questions.text: A girl presented with multiple episodes of loss of consciousness. The episodes usually happen in the presence of the family members in the morning. She regains consciousness after 15 to 30 minutes and usually remembers the events during these episodes. There is no history of tongue bite or urinary incontinence. What should be done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Start behavioural therapy
The girl’s episodes of loss of consciousness suggest conversion
disorder. The best management is behavioral therapy to address
her symptoms and underlying stressors. Conversion disorder, or
functional neurological symptom disorder, involves symptoms
affecting motor or sensory functions due to psychological
factors, often triggered by stress. These symptoms are not
intentionally produced or due to substance use, and the primary
gain is psychological rather than social or legal.

questions.text: In the Motivation model of health education, there are three stages for the adoption of new ideas. What is the third one other than awareness & motivation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Action
The third stage in the Motivation model of health education is
action, following awareness and motivation. In the awareness
stage, individuals gain information about health needs, which is
crucial for making changes. The motivation stage involves
curiosity, evaluation, and decision-making, where individuals
consider the pros and cons of adopting new behaviors, often
requiring support from peers and family.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G4P3L3, with 1 neonatal death (NND) and 2 previous lower segment cesarean sections (LSCS), presents at term with an active genital herpes infection. What is the preferred mode of delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Elective LSCS 
For women with active genital herpes at the time of labor, elective cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery to prevent neonatal herpes transmission. A standard lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is typically performed unless there are other complications necessitating a different approach.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a history of smoking for 20 years decides to quit this habit. However, he develops symptoms of tobacco withdrawal. Which of the following symptoms is unlikely to be seen in him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tachycardia
In the given scenario, the patient has symptoms of tobacco withdrawal. So, tachycardia is unlikely to be seen in him. Patients with tobacco withdrawal usually have a decreased heart rate.

questions.text: The functioning of the thyroid involves the transport of iodine from the blood to the thyroid follicle. Iodine is transported from the follicle to the colloid. Which pump or channel is for transport of iodine from the follicle to the colloid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pendrin
Pendrin is the channel responsible for transporting iodine from
the follicle to the colloid in thyroid hormone synthesis. The
process begins with iodide uptake via the sodium-iodide
symporter (NIS) in the basolateral membrane, which actively
transports iodide into follicular cells. Then, pendrin transports it
into the colloid. Thyroglobulin (Tg), a glycoprotein rich in
tyrosine, is synthesized by follicular cells. Iodination of Tg is
regulated by thyroid peroxidase (TPO), which oxidizes iodide to
iodine, links iodine to tyrosine residues to form
monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT), and couples
these to produce triiodothyronine (T3) and tetraiodothyronine
(T4). Thyroid hormones are stored in colloid form bound to Tg
for 2-3 months. Upon release, iodinated Tg is endocytosed,
cleaved by lysosomal enzymes into MIT, DIT, T3, and T4, with
T4 (80%) and T3 (20%) released into the bloodstream. T4 is
converted to the active form T3 in peripheral tissues. Pendred
syndrome, caused by mutations in pendrin, results in goiter and
sensorineural hearing loss.

choices.text: Initially the pH of tubular fluid increases
Low pH normally decreases bicarbonate excretion
It takes hours to days for kidney to synthesize enzymes that produce NH4+
Other ions in the tubule interfere with buffer action

questions.text: Renal compensation in metabolic acidosis takes time because:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) It takes hours to days for kidney to synthesize enzymes that produce NH4+ Compensation in metabolic acidosis happens late in the kidney because it takes hours to days for it to synthesize enzymes that produce NH4+(ammonium ions). Acid-base balance equation: CO2 + H20> H2CO3 -> H+ (acid) and HCO3-(base) - First line of defence (in seconds): Buffers (phosphate and ammonium) - Second line of defence (in Minutes): Lungs - Third line of defence (in hours days): Kidney The kidneys regulate the acid-base balance by two major mechanisms the reabsorption of bicarbonate and the generation of new bicarbonate via ammonia production and distal nephron acid secretion. Urinary NH4+ is produced primarily in the proximal tubule cells by converting glutamine to glutamate.

questions.text: The resting membrane potential (RMP) of the nerve is -70mV. Increased permeability of which ion is responsible for the RMP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Potassium
Increased permeability of potassium ions(K+) is responsible for
the RMP of a nerve as there are more K+ channels open at rest,
facilitating the flow of potassium ions across the membrane.
Resting membrane potential (RMP) is the difference in the
electrical potentials between the cytoplasm of the cell and the
extracellular space.
At rest, there are more open K+ channels compared to Na+
channels, thus the membrane permeability of K+ is greater. As a
result of this, the intracellular and extracellular K+
concentrations are the major determinants of the RMP.
Furthermore, the RMP is close to the equilibrium potential of
K+ in general.

choices.text: Free serum iron is toxic to cells
Iron is stored in the body in the form of ferritin
Serum ferritin denotes the iron levels in the body
Iron is transported by binding with apoferritin

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about iron metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Iron is transported by binding with apoferritin
Iron is transported by ferroportin, not apoferritin. Apoferritin is
a storage form of iron found in the intestinal mucosa, where it
binds and stores iron by forming ferritin with ferric hydroxidephosphate.
Iron absorption occurs in the duodenum, with two
forms: non-heme and heme iron. Non-heme iron is mostly in the
Fe3+ (ferric) state and is reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous) by
ferrireductases like duodenal cytochrome B. Fe2+ is transported
into the cells via divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1). Heme
iron is taken up through heme transporters. Inside duodenal
cells, Fe2+ can be sent into circulation via ferroportin or stored
as mucosal iron. Hephaestin, associated with ferroportin,
facilitates basolateral transport but is not a transporter itself.

choices.text: Acetylcholine release – Calcium entry- Na+ entry
Calcium entry- Acetylcholine release- Na+ entry
Na+ entry – Calcium entry – Acetylcholine release
Na+ entry – Acetylcholine release – Calcium entry

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of steps involved at neuromuscular
junction endplate potential.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Calcium entry- Acetylcholine release- Na+ entry
The sequence of steps involved at neuromuscular junction
endplate potential is Calcium entry- Acetylcholine release-Na+
entry.

questions.text: In which stage of sleep are K complex and sleep spindles seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stage 2 NREM
Stage 2 of NREM sleep is marked by the appearance of sinusoidal waves called sleep spindles (12-14 Hz) and occasional high-voltage biphasic waves called K complexes.

questions.text: What is the resting membrane potential of the sinoatrial (SA) node?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

-55 to-60mv
The resting membrane potential (RMP) of the sinoatrial (SA) node is -55 to-60 millivolts.

questions.text: A scientist found that the latent period of muscle twitch is 10 ms and the contraction period is 40 ms. What is the tetanizing frequency (Hz)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

25
Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1/40 ms = 25 Hz.

questions.text: Where will you find the epithelium shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ureter The epithelium shown in the above image can be found in the ureter. The ureter is lined by transitional epithelium (also called urothelium), similar to the urinary bladder. This specialized epithelium allows stretching, which is crucial as the urine passes through. The presence of transitional epithelium is characteristic of structures in the urinary system, such as the ureters, bladder, and part of the urethra.

questions.text: During the examination of a patient, a professor asks the patient to invert his foot and points to a prominent tendon located behind the medial malleolus. Which tendon is being highlighted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tibialis posterior
The tendon being highlighted here is of the tibialis posterior.
It passes behind the medial malleolus and is a key muscle
responsible for foot inversion. The tendon of this muscle
becomes prominent in this area during foot inversion.
Dysfunction of this tendon can lead to flatfoot deformity.

questions.text: An elderly woman reports difficulty in buttoning her shirt and increased clumsiness during daily activities. On examination, she is unable to make an ‘O’ shape by opposing her thumb and index finger. Which of the following muscles is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Abductor pollicis brevis
The difficulty in buttoning the shirt and the inability to make the
“O” shape with fingers suggest the involvement of the abductor
pollicis brevis muscle.
This is a case of anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) syndrome.
The AIN is a purely motor branch of the median nerve that
affects specific muscles in the forearm, the flexor pollicis longus
and flexor digitorum profundus leading to difficulty in
performing tasks requiring fine motor control, such as the “OK”
sign. Among the options provided, the abductor pollicis brevis is
uniquely and consistently innervated by the recurrent motor
branch of the median nerve, making it susceptible to dysfunction
in conditions affecting the median nerve.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with weakness of shoulder movements. Investigations revealed quadrangular space syndrome. Which of the following nerve is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Axillary nerve

The axillary nerve is likely to be affected as it is one of the contents of the quadrangular space. Quadrangular space syndrome is a condition caused by hypertrophy or fibrosis of the quadrangular space muscles which impinge on the axillary nerve. Patients present with weakness of the shoulder movements.

questions.text: The labyrinthine artery most commonly arises from which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (AICA)
The labyrinthine artery is most commonly a branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA). It can also be a direct branch of the basilar artery at times.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve nuclei is not a part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Trochlear nerve
The trochlear nerve nucleus is a part of the general somatic efferent (GSE) column, not the special visceral afferent column. The trochlear nerve is a motor nerve that innervates superior oblique muscle in the orbit.
